commit_message:
Update identity endpoints when switching to ssl

When keystone recieves certificates down the certificates relation
it needs to update the identity endpoint to https.

Change-Id: I9a423096b77a73f78a6cc9e3d250bdea2fb861b6

commit_message:
Implement Trust Flush via keystone-manage.

Creates a cli entry 'trust_flush' which removes
all expired trusts.

Change-Id: I1c85b67d24e05db86c85e722fbd773a411c24ac4
Closes-Bug: #1473292

Implement Trust Flush via keystone-manage.

all expired trusts.

commit_message:
Stop running non voting jobs in the gate

The gate shouldn't run non voting jobs because these jobs have no input
on whether or not the changes will merge. Remove all non voting jobs
from the gate queues as a result.

Change-Id: I5a939b5eb34ec2bc06fcc826d5bd193136d5ac81

'}, {'created': '2018-10-26 14:01:10.000000000', 'message': "Add default distro packages for wheel builds

There are some packages which absolutely must be there
for all wheel builds, or for installing without wheels.
Without them, pip is totally unable to compile the
package due to missing headers or tooling.

This patch adds a default, minimal, set of compilers
and python headers.

Rather than use include_vars, with_first_found as we
do in most other roles, we use vars/main and a dict
based on ansible_os_family. The role is often included
by other roles, and we'd rather not risk the search
path being incorrect (there are constant bugs related
to this in ansible). Using this mechanism takes away
the need for an include_vars task and avoids any pathing
issues.

Change-Id: I4ef11e47e4d3fe5adc65e9888e660a5a121d205b

commit_message:
Add default distro packages for wheel builds

There are some packages which absolutely must be there
for all wheel builds, or for installing without wheels.
Without them, pip is totally unable to compile the
package due to missing headers or tooling.

This patch adds a default, minimal, set of compilers
and python headers.

Rather than use include_vars, with_first_found as we
do in most other roles, we use vars/main and a dict
based on ansible_os_family. The role is often included
by other roles, and we'd rather not risk the search
path being incorrect (there are constant bugs related
to this in ansible). Using this mechanism takes away
the need for an include_vars task and avoids any pathing
issues.

Change-Id: I4ef11e47e4d3fe5adc65e9888e660a5a121d205b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-22 19:43:58.000000000', 'message': 'conductor: Recreate volume attachments during a reschedule

When an instance with attached volumes fails to spawn, cleanup code
within the compute manager (_shutdown_instance called from
_build_resources) will delete the volume attachments referenced by
the bdms in Cinder. As a result we should check and if necessary
recreate these volume attachments when rescheduling an instance.

Note that there are a few different ways to fix this bug by
making changes to the compute manager code, either by not deleting
the volume attachment on failure before rescheduling [1] or by
performing the get/create check during each build after the
reschedule [2].

The problem with *not* cleaning up the attachments is if we don't
reschedule, then we've left orphaned "reserved" volumes in Cinder
(or we have to add special logic to tell compute when to cleanup
attachments).

The problem with checking the existence of the attachment on every
new host we build on is that we'd be needlessly checking that for
initial creates even if we don't ever need to reschedule, unless
again we have special logic against that (like checking to see if
we've rescheduled at all).

Also, in either case that involves changes to the compute means that
older computes might not have the fix.

So ultimately it seems that the best way to handle this is:

1. Only deal with this on reschedules.
2. Let the cell conductor orchestrate it since it's already dealing
   with the reschedule. Then the compute logic doesn't need to change.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/587071/3/nova/compute/manager.py@1631
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/587071/4/nova/compute/manager.py@1667

Change-Id: I739c06bd02336bf720cddacb21f48e7857378487
Closes-bug: #1784353
(cherry picked from commit 41452a5c6adb8cae54eef24803f4adc468131b34)

commit_message:
conductor: Recreate volume attachments during a reschedule

When an instance with attached volumes fails to spawn, cleanup code
within the compute manager (_shutdown_instance called from
_build_resources) will delete the volume attachments referenced by
the bdms in Cinder. As a result we should check and if necessary
recreate these volume attachments when rescheduling an instance.

Note that there are a few different ways to fix this bug by
making changes to the compute manager code, either by not deleting
the volume attachment on failure before rescheduling [1] or by
performing the get/create check during each build after the
reschedule [2].

The problem with *not* cleaning up the attachments is if we don't
reschedule, then we've left orphaned "reserved" volumes in Cinder
(or we have to add special logic to tell compute when to cleanup
attachments).

The problem with checking the existence of the attachment on every
new host we build on is that we'd be needlessly checking that for
initial creates even if we don't ever need to reschedule, unless
again we have special logic against that (like checking to see if
we've rescheduled at all).

Also, in either case that involves changes to the compute means that
older computes might not have the fix.

So ultimately it seems that the best way to handle this is:

1. Only deal with this on reschedules.
2. Let the cell conductor orchestrate it since it's already dealing
   with the reschedule. Then the compute logic doesn't need to change.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/587071/3/nova/compute/manager.py@1631
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/587071/4/nova/compute/manager.py@1667

Change-Id: I739c06bd02336bf720cddacb21f48e7857378487
Closes-bug: #1784353
(cherry picked from commit 41452a5c6adb8cae54eef24803f4adc468131b34)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-04 09:17:17.000000000', 'message': "WIP: switch to new instance failover listener

We had a bunch of issues with the WMI based event listener, which
appear to be bugs in the WMI provider.

We've added a new listener that uses the underlying C library. The
only issue is that this new listener cannot tell us the source of
the migrated VMs, so we'll have to rely on the information from
Nova.

Change-Id: I9e777351eca84274cafc3f04b6bc27c3f6b572ca
"}, {'created': '2018-10-17 08:22:56.000000000', 'message': "Switch to new instance failover listener

We had a bunch of issues with the WMI based event listener, which
appear to be bugs in the WMI provider.

We've added a new listener that uses the underlying C library. The
only issue is that this new listener cannot tell us the source of
the migrated VMs, so we'll have to rely on the information from
Nova.

Closes-Bug: #1798069

Change-Id: I9e777351eca84274cafc3f04b6bc27c3f6b572ca
"}]
commit_message:
Switch to new instance failover listener

We had a bunch of issues with the WMI based event listener, which
appear to be bugs in the WMI provider.

We've added a new listener that uses the underlying C library. The
only issue is that this new listener cannot tell us the source of
the migrated VMs, so we'll have to rely on the information from
Nova.

Closes-Bug: #1798069
Depends-On: I63d1aa3a6f9fb12d08478eb41fe973b1582b540c

Change-Id: I9e777351eca84274cafc3f04b6bc27c3f6b572ca

subject: add () to be compatible with the python3
messages:
[{'account_id': 21486, 'date': '2018-10-31 09:21:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-10-31 19:14:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

This page of the docs is meant to be more of an historical artifact than live, runnable, maintained code. The last of the blog posts these were taken from was published in February 2011! (From the Internet Archive: http://web.archive.org/web/20120420073339/http://www.tlohg.com:80/2011_02_01_archive.html )

*If* we want to make this py2/py3 compatible, I'd really be inclined to move the code out to separate files and `.. literalinclude::` them in the docs. This would have two benefits: we could run pep8 on them, and it would be easier for people to just clone and run the code.

But really, I feel like adding a note in the introduction that

- the content was authored in February 2011,
- as such, all of the code that follows is python2-specific, and
- regardless of language, the state of the art has almost certainly moved on

would be *way* simpler."}, {'account_id': 21486, 'date': '2018-11-01 06:44:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

'}]

commit_message:
Move 4byte_asn scenario test to basic dir

Since a separate job has not been created [0], move the scenario test
into the basic directory so that it will be executed there.

Set TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY=1 for the basic scenario job in order to avoid
resource collisions.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/529256

Change-Id: Idbf2739a585473fdf1d364ad1ee263ad359fd750

check commands. For now it has only "check_placeholder"
check implemented.
Real checks can be added to this tool in the future.

subject: Remove empty directories after a revert job
messages:
[{'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-10-17 14:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-10-17 14:15:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

The context of this is: we have some infras when the reconstructor will take a very long time to process a disk. We have ad hoc scripts to cleanup reverted partition tree. (not waiting for the second pass of the reconstructor)

This, along with a19548b3e692182b3b228f932e821861eb2c8699 (Remove empty part dirs during ssync replication) means that everything will be removed after a succesful revert, except the top level partition dir.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-10-17 15:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

this sounds familiar, is it similar to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565616/

Or this maybe?  https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1413407'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-10-17 21:02:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

> this sounds familiar, is it similar to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565616/

I think they're probably related but separate. Or Sam's patch was just a partial fix, and we missed this case, maybe? The changes to test_purge_already_removed really seem to demonstrate what's wrong with the current behavior and what we'd like to see instead.

Seems to make sense, gimme a day or two to find time to try it out and really see the bad for myself."}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-10-18 20:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Thank you guys for your review.
It is similar to  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565616/ , the issue with that one is that it will remove the hashpath only in cleanup_ondisk_files() , and the suffix and partition path in _update_suffix_hashes(). 
This will not happen on the first pass of the reconstructor.

With the proposed patch, if the revert job is successful, only the partition path and hashes.* file remain.'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-10-26 07:36:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

This looks surprisingly okay to me.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-10-31 22:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Remove empty directories after a revert job

Currently, the reconstructor will not remove empty object and suffixes
directories after processing a revert job. This will only happen during
its next run.

This patch will attempt to remove these empty directories immediately,
while we have the inodes cached.

Change-Id: I5dfc145b919b70ab7dae34fb124c8a25ba77222f

commit_message:
DVR: Avoid address scope rules for dvr_no_external agents

All FloatingIP for DVR_NO_EXTERNAL agents will be configured
in the SNAT Namespace. So there is no need to configure the
address scope related routes in the router namespace when the
agent is configured as DVR_NO_EXTERNAL.

Change-Id: I009dae9e7f485641f2f19dce8dd575da04bfb044
Related-Bug: #1753434
(cherry picked from commit 7c4da6fb756189e6afc1c699e06ce74488c61d45)

Due to recent issues in the gate and the fact that we're using way too
much CI resources, I think it is time to switch the scenario jobs to
non-voting to reduce the amount of load we are using upstream. These
jobs need to be replaced with voting standalone jobs going forward.

See also:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/136141.html

Change-Id: I605a11a900197cc9188156ae74412cc54f1df943

commit_message:
Switch scenarios to non-voting

Due to recent issues in the gate and the fact that we're using way too
much CI resources, I think it is time to switch the scenario jobs to
non-voting to reduce the amount of load we are using upstream. These
jobs need to be replaced with voting standalone jobs going forward.

See also:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/136141.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135396.html

Change-Id: I605a11a900197cc9188156ae74412cc54f1df943

fallback to USE_SUDO only if this fails.

pip version.

commit_message:
Make quickstack.sh avoid needing sudo on missing virtualenv

Attempt to install virtualenv at user level if not detected and
fallback to USE_SUDO only if this fails.

Avoids silly warnings about old pip on tasks that do upgrade
pip version.

Solves failure on fedora-26 where no match on wildcards triggers
an error, as oposed to the other supported platforms where this
is not changing the result code.

Validates that python modules can be imported and prints their version
on single final line.

Change-Id: Iac6d311cc4bc6788450ee02d140950d1692d7dd8
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/613920/
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/153

commit_message:
Fix python3 detection logic

The python_cmd function code is copied from already merged
tripleo-quicstart/quickstart.sh version.

In the future we plan to use it form a single location.

Previous version was using python3 on CentOS-7 if it was installed
which was not desired behavior.

Change-Id: Id03b7ff76054c807e46c2483510313b4de66d678
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/153

commit_message:
remove external_network_bridge option

The external_network_bridge option is deprecated/legacy and being
removed from neutron [1].
This patch removes the external_network_bridge option iniset from
training-labs repo.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567369/

lookup named" message. Fix that replacing loop with with_list.

[{'created': '2018-10-18 14:43:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add manage_backend_package parameter

Adds the manage_backend_package parameter that is sent
to the oslo::cache class that determines if we should
install the backend python library for caching.

The default value is not changed and defaults to true

Change-Id: I8a99eee7622e25847c2d729fa97d0500fe27d8f4

commit_message:
Add manage_backend_package parameter

Adds the manage_backend_package parameter that is sent
to the oslo::cache class that determines if we should
install the backend python library for caching.

The default value is not changed and defaults to true
same as the oslo::cache class does.

Change-Id: I8a99eee7622e25847c2d729fa97d0500fe27d8f4
(cherry picked from commit f882e39447506eb500e3211df786c7d21b84d792)

commit_message:
Add capabilities for privsep

CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE and CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH were added
(like in nova) to fix agents on kernel 4.15.
Please see bug for details

Change-Id: Ieed6f5f6906036cdeaf2c3d96350eeae9559c0c7
Closes-Bug: #1800157
(cherry picked from commit 32cc8b63d7bbe5cfc83b82a058d1c5832980f290)

(2 comments)

One little concern, but I *think* I'm OK with things as-is -- the tests aren't exactly representative of reality (the reconstructor's headers would never include a replicated storage policy), but w/e."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-10-31 20:12:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

It looks like we're already +A, but I'll address the questions in case we ever have to refer back to this review.

Thanks Tim!"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-30 16:45:24.000000000', 'message': 'Use correct headers in reconstructor requests

As long as the reconstructor collects parts from all policies each job
must be considered to have it's storage policy index and we can't use
global state for policy specific headers.  It's good hygiene to avoid
mutating the global state regardless.

Under load with multiple policies we observed essentially empty handoff
parts "re-appearing" on nodes until adding these changes.

Closes-Bug: #1671180
Change-Id: Id0e5f2743e05d81da7b26b2f05c90ba3c68e4d72
'}, {'created': '2018-10-31 13:42:01.000000000', 'message': 'Use correct headers in reconstructor requests

As long as the reconstructor collects parts from all policies each job
must be considered to have it's storage policy index and we can't use
global state for policy specific headers.  It's good hygiene to avoid
mutating the global state regardless.

Under load with multiple policies we observed essentially empty handoff
parts "re-appearing" on nodes until adding these changes.

Closes-Bug: #1671180
Change-Id: Id0e5f2743e05d81da7b26b2f05c90ba3c68e4d72
'}]
commit_message:
Use correct headers in reconstructor requests

As long as the reconstructor collects parts from all policies each job
must be considered to have it's storage policy index and we can't use
global state for policy specific headers.  It's good hygiene to avoid
mutating the global state regardless.

Under load with multiple policies we observed essentially empty handoff
parts "re-appearing" on nodes until adding these changes.

Closes-Bug: #1671180
Change-Id: Id0e5f2743e05d81da7b26b2f05c90ba3c68e4d72

commit_message:
Deprecate eventlet related configuration

The "standard-threads", "pydev-debug-host" and "pydev-debug-port"
cli configuration items were only used by Keystone eventlet model
in Newton release. Deprecate them now.

Change-Id: If4f2f318999fc291ce93b12ce57a95dfca5dcf05
bp: deprecated-as-of-stein

commit_message:
Add OpenStack clients service

We did not have a easy way to ensure all the openstack clients are
installed on a given system. In the old instack-undercloud installation,
we were installing some additional clients outside of the ones required
via python-tripleoclient. To allow a user to quickly install all the
clients on a given system, this change adds an OpenStack clients
"service" which can be added to a role to ensure the clients are
available. In the future if we provide a client container, this service
can be converted into a container deployment mechanism.

Change-Id: If878c2ab7679eea2fff42b410bec9c8c9b92ed6f
Closes-Bug: #1800001

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-21 17:02:18.000000000', 'message': 'hacking: Add hacking rule for plugin rbac test class names

This patch set introduces a new hacking check called
`no_plugin_rbac_test_suffix_in_plugin_test_class_name` which
is responsible for enforcing that all plugin rbac test classes
end in the correct suffix in order to avoid issues like [0].

Basically, some network plugin rbac tests were skipping because
the regex in .zuul.yaml was not selecting them because the
classes were improperly named. This is to avoid that regression.

Updates documentation with P104 - alias for this new hacking
rule - and adds unit tests to validate its logic.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/612197/

Change-Id: Ia50edbe5aeb25e57756e9579da8270396bba718c

commit_message:
hacking: Add hacking rule for plugin rbac test class names

This patch set introduces a new hacking check called
`no_plugin_rbac_test_suffix_in_plugin_test_class_name` which
is responsible for enforcing that all plugin rbac test classes
end in the correct suffix in order to avoid issues like [0].

Basically, some network plugin rbac tests were skipping because
the regex in .zuul.yaml was not selecting them because the
classes were improperly named. This is to avoid that regression.

Updates documentation with P104 - alias for this new hacking
rule - and adds unit tests to validate its logic.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/612197/

Change-Id: Ia50edbe5aeb25e57756e9579da8270396bba718c

commit_message:
(squash) disabling podman everywhere in gate

Until we fix the situation, we want to remove podman from our gate.

Revert "fs010: switch undercloud to podman"

This reverts commit 39d1da5267724244d4d1f0bfabae187e4bfcfa92.

Revert "fs050: upgrade the undercloud to Podman containers"

This reverts commit ab6cbcb0cea3c296b6ee5b873c9b9c08ba8285b2.

Revert "Switch fs027 to deploy with podman"

This reverts commit f77771843fe60d370135ce345b680be0209082e4.

Change-Id: I3715a0432ead1eb1d18deb5893858e051a0b5539
Related-Bug: #1800737

commit_message:

Currently, README.rst does not mention about Wiki page and Mailing
List as contact point to community. So this patch aims to add an
URL that links to Wiki page and Mailing List tag in `External
Resources` session.

commit_message:
Resource retrieving: add changes-before filter

This adds the changes-before filter to the servers,
os-instance-actions and os-migrations APIs for
filtering resources which were last updated before
or equal to the given time. The changes-before filter,
like the changes-since filter, will return deleted
server resources.

Part of bp support-to-query-nova-resources-filter-by-changes-before
Change-Id: If91c179e3823c8b0da744a9363906b0f7b05c326

[{'created': '2018-10-31 21:04:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix stopping of PeriodicWorker

Patch [1] for oslo.service started using eventlet Event for
loopingcall events.
It may now happen (at least in UT) that stop event is sent when
other event was already sent and that can cause AssertionError
in eventlet.event module.

To avoid that, we should check if self._loop is not None but also
if it is running before stop() method will be called.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/611807/

Closes-Bug #1800879

Change-Id: I1febe5b5a151b251d0b88e65ced7a1715fd47e05
'}]
commit_message:
Fix stopping of PeriodicWorker

Patch [1] for oslo.service started using eventlet Event for
loopingcall events.
It may now happen (at least in UT) that stop event is sent when
other event was already sent and that can cause AssertionError
in eventlet.event module.

To avoid that, we should check if self._loop is not None but also
if it is running before stop() method will be called.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/611807/

Closes-Bug #1800879

Change-Id: I1febe5b5a151b251d0b88e65ced7a1715fd47e05

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-21 16:32:17.000000000', 'message': 'fix: Rename test classes causing accidental skip

This patch set renames two classes that are neutron plugin

commit_message:
fix: Rename test classes causing accidental skip

This patch set renames two classes that are neutron plugin
rbac tests but don't end in the appropriate suffix of
"PluginRbacTest" which is used by .zuul.yaml to correctly execute
the tests [0].

This means that, in effect, these tests aren't being run in any
jobs. This patch set resolves the issue.

In a follow up patch set a hacking rule will be added to enforce
correct naming for plugin rbac tests.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/patrole/blob/0c7f83ea1716462737a40cc32f27b95abf4557af/.zuul.yaml#L168

Change-Id: Ieac5ebf70eefcebf1aebc26da95d58fcd68a202e

commit_message:
Add supplement in high-availability.rst about cinder

Cinder volume is making progress in Active-Active
HA mode by distributed lock mechanism.

Change-Id: I1f31c41bdcaa043059fe5e551af9a2cab0ebe74c
Closes-Bug: #1717826

rabbitmq should absolutely not have the hostname of the container, but rather of the host it is running on. The hostname of the container is not-persistent but the rabbitmq data is (stored in a volume).

Additionally, this patch would lose the all the messages in a cluster when upgrading.

If your problem is as you describe it in the bug, then this patch should allow the rabbitmq _interface_ to be configurable, not take this approach at all.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-30 20:16:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

please correct pep8, otherwise I am both hands for this change :)'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2016-12-02 23:16:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

This is a very impactful change which should not be merged in its present state with how its trying to accomplish this.

* This affects upgrades, youll lose all messages in the cluster any time you upgrade rabbitmq containers
* any time a new rabbitmq container is launched and new clusterer config will be created, but you arent properly incrementing the clusterer config
* all messages on a host before recreation will be lost. This basically makes the rabbitmq data volume useless and possibly dangerous

A better way to solve this would be to set the hostname of the rabbitmq container from ansible. That would be upgrade safe too'}, {'account_id': 13671, 'date': '2016-12-04 14:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

i think for safety reason one could add enable_<this_feature> flag so that it would be conditional'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2016-12-05 01:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

this is a broken "feature". What does this "feature" add here is my question.

I know rabbitmq has issue, but this will cause more problems than it solves, especially with clusterer. It would be like if galera had a new hostname everytime it was rebuilt. All the data would be worthless and unaccessible. The potential for dataloss is greatly increased with this patch. Dataloss is an absolute certainty on upgrades as well.'}, {'account_id': 13671, 'date': '2016-12-05 07:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

i cannot agree with such elaboration. If this feature is broken then bare metal role and patching /etc/hosts by hand is also broken, right?'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2016-12-05 10:41:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Perhaps I could be clearer.

It is a hard requirement to have properly functioning DNS setup on the host. If the IP address on the api_interface is not resolving to the hostname, then the operator needs to set that up properly throughout the environment. Whether that be in /etc/hosts or through proper DNS.

Modifying /etc/hosts in this manner is something that should not be done. This goes against kolla-ansible's philosophy of "don't touch the host".

This issue was found a while ago and the solution was to setup a check. If you ran the checks, you would see the environment does not pass the hostname check [1]. Perhaps the correct solution here would be to move this "check" into a place where it always runs. Or simply emphasis running these checks as a prerequisite.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/master/ansible/roles/prechecks/tasks/port_checks.yml#L660-671'}, {'account_id': 14387, 'date': '2017-01-06 20:44:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14387, 'date': '2017-01-06 20:56:48.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bug/1646043 to bug/1583655'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-06 21:11:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

The issue i have with this is we assume "the target node’s primary hostname matches that derived from the api_interface IP" in many sections of this project.

Additionally, there is a precheck designed to catch this particular reconfiguration issue.

This may side step the rabbitmq issue, but you'll still need to set your hostname to match the api_interface for other things to work.'}, {'account_id': 14387, 'date': '2017-01-09 17:46:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> The issue i have with this is we assume "the target node’s primary
 > hostname matches that derived from the api_interface IP" in many
 > sections of this project.
 > 
 > Additionally, there is a precheck designed to catch this particular
 > reconfiguration issue.
 > 
 > This may side step the rabbitmq issue, but you'll still need to set
 > your hostname to match the api_interface for other things to work.

Thats true

there are 2 issue with that 
operators dont always keep the api_interface as rabbit interface sometime they use the network_interface for rabbit 
" 

 > The issue i have with this is we assume "the target node’s primary
 > hostname matches that derived from the api_interface IP" in many
 > sections of this project.
 > 
 > Additionally, there is a precheck designed to catch this particular
 > reconfiguration issue.
 > 
 > This may side step the rabbitmq issue, but you'll still need to set
 > your hostname to match the api_interface for other things to work.

Thats true
sometime operators dont always use the api_interface as rabbit interface the hostname will come from network interface which will be different from api_interface "https://launchpad.net/bugs/1583655"

This patch will allow the operators to use the network interface for rabbit though the api_interface will work on a different interface

The assumption made was api_interface is always primary network interface from which the hostname will come but sometimes operators can have a network interface different than api_interface'}, {'account_id': 14387, 'date': '2017-01-09 17:56:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Published edit on patch set 7'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-09 18:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-11-30 19:53:24.000000000', 'message': 'RabbitMQ cluster should work on api interface

This patch ensures all rabbits are configured to run on api
interface and  have short host names in /etc/hosts on each host.
Rabbit host names are generated and are not looked up in DNS
because of conflicting resolver results on different hosts.
This ensures consistency accross whole RabbitMQ cluster.

Closes-Bug: #1646043

(cherry picked from commit b6c7b8a76ce51830d5395cc8db58ab449c73e2b1
and fixed up merge conflicts accordingly)

Change-Id: I5657a1538aeb69cd4c089e9b0ab5c5c2a6f84d77
'}, {'created': '2016-12-01 19:32:00.000000000', 'message': 'RabbitMQ cluster should work on api interface

This patch ensures all rabbits are configured to run on api
interface and  have short host names in /etc/hosts on each host.
Rabbit host names are generated and are not looked up in DNS
because of conflicting resolver results on different hosts.
This ensures consistency accross whole RabbitMQ cluster.

Closes-Bug: #1646043

Change-Id: I5657a1538aeb69cd4c089e9b0ab5c5c2a6f84d77
'}, {'created': '2017-01-06 20:44:47.000000000', 'message': 'RabbitMQ cluster interface should not depend on primary hostname

In deployments where network_interface and api_interface are different,
Kolla assumes the primary hostname of the target nodes is based on the api_interface.
Some operators may want to base the primary hostname on the network_interface.
In such a deployment scenario, RabbitMQ deployment fails due to the deployment
task assuming the target node’s primary hostname matches that derived from the
api_interface IP.  This update maintains the existing default of pinning RabbitMQ
to the api_interface, but allows for a custom interface to be defined via the
rabbitmq_interface parameter introduced. As long as the interface IP’s are registered
in DNS, an operator is not bound to the interface from which the primary hostname is set.
Finally, this update doesn’t manipulate local /etc/hosts files on the host system,
conforming to Kolla best practices.

Closes-Bug: #1646043

Change-Id: I5657a1538aeb69cd4c089e9b0ab5c5c2a6f84d77

In such a deployment scenario, RabbitMQ deployment fails due to the deployment
task assuming the target node’s primary hostname matches that derived from the
api_interface IP.  This update maintains the existing default of pinning RabbitMQ
to the api_interface, but allows for a custom interface to be defined via the
rabbitmq_interface parameter introduced. As long as the interface IP’s are registered
in DNS, an operator is not bound to the interface from which the primary hostname is set.
Finally, this update doesn’t manipulate local /etc/hosts files on the host system,
conforming to Kolla best practices.

Closes-Bug: #1583655

Change-Id: I5657a1538aeb69cd4c089e9b0ab5c5c2a6f84d77

commit_message:
RabbitMQ cluster interface should not depend on primary hostname

In deployments where network_interface and api_interface are different,
Kolla assumes the primary hostname of the target nodes is based on the
api_interface. Some operators may want to base the primary hostname on
the network_interface. In such a deployment scenario, RabbitMQ
deployment fails due to the deployment task assuming the target node’s
primary hostname matches that derived from the api_interface IP.
This update maintains the existing default of pinning RabbitMQ to the
api_interface, but allows for a custom interface to be defined via the
rabbitmq_interface parameter introduced. As long as the interface IP’s
are registered in DNS, an operator is not bound to the interface from
which the primary hostname is set. Finally, this update doesn’t
manipulate local /etc/hosts files on the host system,
conforming to Kolla best practices.

Closes-Bug: #1583655

Change-Id: I5657a1538aeb69cd4c089e9b0ab5c5c2a6f84d77

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I7ca8ecdaaf61337eaed2df9b0679097672ec53e6

commit_message:
Don't quote {posargs} in tox.ini

Quotes around {posargs} cause the entire string to be combined into one
arg that gets passed to stestr. This prevents passing multiple args
(e.g. '--concurrency=16 some-regex')

Change-Id: I7c45e4525f255deec7c79ae567cf4b1dda111a4a

commit_message:
Don't try to run issubclass on non-classes

issubclass gets cranky if you give it a first argument that is not a
class.

  http://logs.openstack.org/74/612474/2/check/cross-osc-build-sphinx-docs/42250a7/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-10-26_08_02_08_597700

Shows a failure when trying to build python-openstackclient docs with
the cliff sphinxext after updating openstacksdk in such a way that an
import error went away.

Change-Id: Id1d17c66e5dd6e430376a8d6ea74abc4da5cbc75

commit_message:
Set user message on volume create failure

This patch is to log user message when volume creation fails.
This is only for _create_raw_volume, and other patches will be
submitted for _create_from_snapshot etc.

Change-Id: I9ba87863623a9c5806e93b69e1992cabce2f13b9
Partial-Bug: #1799159

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 19:24:50.000000000', 'message': 'opt in for neutron-lib consumption patches

As part of the Denver PTG [1] we decided networking related projects
that are "current" and want to receive neutron-lib consumption patches
on an on-going basis should indicate such with a well defined comment
in their requirements.txt. This allows us to easily find the list of
project to receive neutron-lib consumption patches [2] by searching for
the string.

In addition, projects opting-in for these patches are also attesting
they will stay up to date with TC and infra initiatives to ensure
consumption patches can flow freely.

This patch adds the "neutron-lib-current" string to requirements.txt
opting in for neutron-lib consumption patches.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-stein-ptg
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron-lib/latest/contributor/contributing.html#phase-4-consume

Change-Id: Ie153c218d631ad373881d8bf39617b8483342988
'}]
commit_message:
opt in for neutron-lib consumption patches

As part of the Denver PTG [1] we decided networking related projects
that are "current" and want to receive neutron-lib consumption patches
on an on-going basis should indicate such with a well defined comment
in their requirements.txt. This allows us to easily find the list of
project to receive neutron-lib consumption patches [2] by searching for
the string.

In addition, projects opting-in for these patches are also attesting
they will stay up to date with TC and infra initiatives to ensure
consumption patches can flow freely.

This patch adds the "neutron-lib-current" string to requirements.txt
opting in for neutron-lib consumption patches.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-stein-ptg
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron-lib/latest/contributor/contributing.html#phase-4-consume

Change-Id: Ie153c218d631ad373881d8bf39617b8483342988

commit_message:
WIP When IPv4 address is not available, return IPv6

Network interface can have IPv4 and IPv6 adresses.
Return IPv4 by default but if it is not available
then try to return IPv6.

This change does not include ipv6 specific formats
like 'inet6[1::1]'

Partially implements: blueprint ipv6-control-plane
Change-Id: Ib1ac078ae31a006b9f53a7e1436a0bc8ecc4b5a0
Signed-off-by: Maciej Kucia <maciej@kucia.net>

commit_message:
Make tunnel timeout for nova_serialconsole_proxy configurable

Currently, the serial consoles as accessed through Horizon,
timeout after the haproxy_client_timeout (default: 1m) of
inactivity. This change allows you to set a larger timeout.

Change-Id: I2a9923cb69d5db976395146685aded83922c4120
Closes-Bug: #1800643

commit_message:
Add feature flag for Keystone policies removed in Stein

This patch set adds a new feature flag called
``removed_keystone_policies_stein`` under the configuration
group ``[policy-feature-enabled]`` for skipping Keystone
tests whose policies were removed in Stein. This feature flag
is currently applied to credentials-related policies, e.g.:
identity:[create|update|get|delete]_credential

More info on removed Keystone policies:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/597187/16

Change-Id: Ibd16e658d0e1367b46a2d6730f2b6970a95ae221

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-29 21:44:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix latest flake8 issues

The latest flake8 checks strings for escape chars, and also has a new
and better rule about line breaks before binary operators - which is
what knuth says should happen.

The escape char check was catching some asterisks in docstrings that
weren't actually providing much, since we already list type as "kwargs".
Just remove them.

Install latest flake8 so we can gate on this.

Change-Id: I89088adcc6f4ff5a894df5e677ae9b28a58edd9a
'}]
commit_message:
Fix latest flake8 issues

The latest flake8 checks strings for escape chars, and also has a new
and better rule about line breaks before binary operators - which is
what knuth says should happen.

The escape char check was catching some asterisks in docstrings that
weren't actually providing much, since we already list type as "kwargs".
Just remove them.

Install latest flake8 so we can gate on this.

Change-Id: I89088adcc6f4ff5a894df5e677ae9b28a58edd9a

[{'created': '2018-10-08 21:05:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add regression test for bug 1796737

Change I0839470c4bcfb16590a0d87b306d683b059bf8a9 fixed
root disk reporting for volume-backed servers during
an instance claim which is used during server create
and unshelve. However, resize claims track usage a bit
differently so local_gb_used reporting of a volume-backed
instance is still wrong. This adds a test to exhibit the
bug during resize.

The test was copied and modified from original change:

  https://review.openstack.org/428505/

Co-Authored-By: melanie witt <melwittt@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Iff6dc19f7f9eae3b6350fe6db7c08901d33f53e1
Related-Bug: #1796737
'}]
commit_message:
Add regression test for bug 1796737

Change I0839470c4bcfb16590a0d87b306d683b059bf8a9 fixed
root disk reporting for volume-backed servers during
an instance claim which is used during server create
and unshelve. However, resize claims track usage a bit
differently so local_gb_used reporting of a volume-backed
instance is still wrong. This adds a test to exhibit the
bug during resize.

The test was copied and modified from original change:

  https://review.openstack.org/428505/

Co-Authored-By: melanie witt <melwittt@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Iff6dc19f7f9eae3b6350fe6db7c08901d33f53e1
Related-Bug: #1796737

commit_message:
fixtures: Track volume attachments within CinderFixtureNewAttachFlow

Previously volume attachments ids were not tracked at all within the
fixture with only the instance_uuid and volume_id stashed. This change
should allow future functional tests to exercise bugs where attachments
are deleted but not recreated such as bug #1784353.

Change-Id: Ib30144596fe6a8d8ffbb4ebd695ebcf38ef828a4
Co-authored-by: Matthew Booth <mbooth@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1784353
(cherry picked from commit bfdc6a0d5293e29d91d4755370c08769394f3ba7)

[{'created': '2018-10-29 16:57:43.000000000', 'message': 'No longer call _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj from upt flow

With change I72c83a95dabd581998470edb9543079acb6536a5 we no
longer have a need to call _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj for
in-tree drivers that implement the update_provider_tree() interface.
That change also documented the expectation on the upt interface
that virt drivers should report allocation ratios and reserved
amounts if necessary, like the libvirt driver does with config
option values.

This change removes the call to _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj
from the ResourceTracker when the virt driver implements the
update_provider_tree() method.

Change-Id: Ib3591f583453d98245382be0f7a04b6195d67106
Related-Bug: #1799727
'}]
commit_message:
No longer call _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj from upt flow

With change I72c83a95dabd581998470edb9543079acb6536a5 we no
longer have a need to call _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj for
in-tree drivers that implement the update_provider_tree() interface.
That change also documented the expectation on the upt interface
that virt drivers should report allocation ratios and reserved
amounts if necessary, like the libvirt driver does with config
option values.

This change removes the call to _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj
from the ResourceTracker when the virt driver implements the
update_provider_tree() method.

Change-Id: Ib3591f583453d98245382be0f7a04b6195d67106
Related-Bug: #1799727

Yeah I think that would also work. It's kind of gross tight coupling, but an argument could be made that once you implement update_provider_tree, you're on your own for setting allocation_ratio/reserved host inventory values since the RT can't reliably do it for you."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-29 14:08:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The downside to doing it in the driver's update_provider_tree method is then all virt drivers have to eventually set it via config and we can't control it "globally" in the RT...but the _normalize method in the RT was a bridge helper method anyway so maybe that's not such a big deal.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-29 14:56:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Discussed solutions to this in the scheduler/placement meeting today, this was the summary:

(9:51:55 AM) efried: #agreed It is the responsibility of the virt driver's update_provider_tree to set reserved/allocation_ratio values, initial and otherwise, rocky and master and future. _normalize_inventory_from_cn shall DIAF. revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-24 17:54:18.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Update allocation_ratios in placement inventory if config changes

The purpose of the RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj method is
to set allocation_ratio and reserved amounts on inventory records
that get sent to placement if the virt driver did not specifically
set a ratio or reserved value (which none but the ironic driver do).

If the allocation_ratio or reserved amount is in the inventory
data dict from the virt driver, then the normalize method ignores
it and lets the virt driver take priority.

However, with change I6a706ec5966cdc85f97223617662fe15d3e6dc08,
any virt driver that implements the update_provider_tree() interface
is storing the inventory data on the ProviderTree object which gets
cached and re-used, meaning once allocation_ratio/reserved is set
from RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj, it doesn't get unset and
the normalize method always assumes the driver provided a value which
should not be changed, even if the configuration value changes.

We can make the config option changes take effect by changing
_normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj to update the allocation_ratio if
the config has a value. Since the allocation ratio config options
default to 0.0, if they are not set, they evaluate to False.
We can also control this behavior to only overwrite what is in the
inventory dict if we're using the update_provider_tree() flow.

Change-Id: I72c83a95dabd581998470edb9543079acb6536a5
Closes-Bug: #1799727
"}, {'created': '2018-10-24 19:28:19.000000000', 'message': "Update reserved/allocation_ratio in placement inventory if config changes

any virt driver that implements the update_provider_tree() interface
is storing the inventory data on the ProviderTree object which gets

from RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj, it doesn't get unset and
the normalize method always assumes the driver provided a value which
should not be changed, even if the configuration value changes.

We can make the config option changes take effect by changing
_normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj to update reserved/allocation_ratio
if the config has a value. Since the allocation ratio config options
default to 0.0, if they are not set, they evaluate to False.
We can also control this behavior to only overwrite what is in the

Change-Id: I72c83a95dabd581998470edb9543079acb6536a5
Closes-Bug: #1799727
"}, {'created': '2018-10-25 14:09:11.000000000', 'message': 'Update reserved/allocation_ratio in placement inventory if config changes

The purpose of the RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj method is
to set allocation_ratio and reserved amounts on standard resource
class inventory records that get sent to placement if the virt driver
did not specifically set a ratio or reserved value (which none but
the ironic driver do).

If the allocation_ratio or reserved amount is in the inventory
data dict from the virt driver, then the normalize method ignores
it and lets the virt driver take priority.

However, with change I6a706ec5966cdc85f97223617662fe15d3e6dc08,
any virt driver that implements the update_provider_tree() interface
is storing the inventory data on the ProviderTree object which gets
cached and re-used, meaning once allocation_ratio/reserved is set
from RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj, it doesn't get unset and
the normalize method always assumes the driver provided a value which
should not be changed, even if the configuration value changes.

We can make the config option changes take effect by changing
_normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj to update reserved/allocation_ratio
if the config has a value. Since the allocation ratio config options
default to 0.0, if they are not set, they evaluate to False.
We can also control this behavior to only overwrite what is in the
inventory dict if we're using the update_provider_tree() flow.
Note that the ironic driver does provide a "reserved" value in
its inventory dict, however, that driver only reports a custom
resource class inventory for which we have no config so
RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj() will not override it.

Change-Id: I72c83a95dabd581998470edb9543079acb6536a5
Closes-Bug: #1799727
'}, {'created': '2018-10-29 16:32:56.000000000', 'message': 'Provide allocation_ratio/reserved amounts from update_provider_tree()

The purpose of the RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj method is
to set allocation_ratio and reserved amounts on standard resource
class inventory records that get sent to placement if the virt driver
did not specifically set a ratio or reserved value (which none but
the ironic driver do).

If the allocation_ratio or reserved amount is in the inventory
data dict from the virt driver, then the normalize method ignores
it and lets the virt driver take priority.

However, with change I6a706ec5966cdc85f97223617662fe15d3e6dc08,
any virt driver that implements the update_provider_tree() interface
is storing the inventory data on the ProviderTree object which gets
cached and re-used, meaning once allocation_ratio/reserved is set
from RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj, it doesn't get unset and
the normalize method always assumes the driver provided a value which
should not be changed, even if the configuration value changes.

We can make the config option changes take effect by changing
the semantics between _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj and
drivers that implement the update_provider_tree interface, like
for the libvirt driver. Effectively with this change, when a driver
implements update_provider_tree(), they now control setting the
allocation_ratio and reserved resource amounts for inventory they
report. The libvirt driver will use the same configuration option
values that _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj used. The only difference
is in update_provider_tree we don't have the ComputeNode facade to
get the "real" default values when the allocation_ratio is 0.0, so
we handle that like "CONF.cpu_allocation_ratio or 16.0". Eventually
that will get cleaned up with blueprint initial-allocation-ratios.

Change-Id: I72c83a95dabd581998470edb9543079acb6536a5
Closes-Bug: #1799727
'}]
commit_message:
Provide allocation_ratio/reserved amounts from update_provider_tree()

The purpose of the RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj method is
to set allocation_ratio and reserved amounts on standard resource
class inventory records that get sent to placement if the virt driver
did not specifically set a ratio or reserved value (which none but
the ironic driver do).

If the allocation_ratio or reserved amount is in the inventory
data dict from the virt driver, then the normalize method ignores
it and lets the virt driver take priority.

However, with change I6a706ec5966cdc85f97223617662fe15d3e6dc08,
any virt driver that implements the update_provider_tree() interface
is storing the inventory data on the ProviderTree object which gets
cached and re-used, meaning once allocation_ratio/reserved is set
from RT._normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj, it doesn't get unset and
the normalize method always assumes the driver provided a value which
should not be changed, even if the configuration value changes.

We can make the config option changes take effect by changing
the semantics between _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj and
drivers that implement the update_provider_tree interface, like
for the libvirt driver. Effectively with this change, when a driver
implements update_provider_tree(), they now control setting the
allocation_ratio and reserved resource amounts for inventory they
report. The libvirt driver will use the same configuration option
values that _normalize_inventory_from_cn_obj used. The only difference
is in update_provider_tree we don't have the ComputeNode facade to
get the "real" default values when the allocation_ratio is 0.0, so
we handle that like "CONF.cpu_allocation_ratio or 16.0". Eventually
that will get cleaned up with blueprint initial-allocation-ratios.

Change-Id: I72c83a95dabd581998470edb9543079acb6536a5
Closes-Bug: #1799727

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

Probably should have had melwitt look at this."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-10-31 18:22:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I'm not sure if removal was the correct thing here, see:
 > 
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bug/1798188+(status:open+OR+status:merged)
 > 
 > Probably should have had melwitt look at this.

I still think it is the correct thing to do. As I understand it, in a new deployment, the nova-consoleauth service should not exist. Similarly, once Rocky has been deployed for long enough on an upgraded deployment, this service will no longer be necessary and should be removed. Perhaps we should have called out that nova-consoleauth might be listed for old deployment or someone that decides to keep it around but I think that's overkill, personally"}]

commit_message:
Remove deprecated nova-consoleauth reference from doc

Because nova-consoleauth had deprecated since version 18.0.0,
it is better not to give reference of this service in verify operation
documentation file.

Change-Id: I0c3b9cfe96bcc3d7b6106c3e972ee9e2f79e419b

Hold for Rocky GA.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-29 19:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-05 00:10:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We don't really need to backport this since it's not fixing a bug. Docs are published from master also so people can get the updates there."}, {'account_id': 25562, 'date': '2018-09-05 03:25:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> We don't really need to backport this since it's not fixing a bug.
 > Docs are published from master also so people can get the updates
 > there.

I had read the stable-branches guide [1] before backporting this. I was aware that the main concern is how important it is for the doc changes to be on the stable branches. Then I was thinking people with rocky deployment might tend to trust rocky version of docs more than the latest ones. And if that is case, this backport might be beneficial to a bunch of people.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#"}, {'account_id': 28239, 'date': '2018-09-05 03:34:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2018-09-20 23:48:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Clean backport. LGTM.'}, {'account_id': 26311, 'date': '2018-09-21 10:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 15:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

OK, clean backport, just docs, so lgtm. Fast approving.'}]

I review the code one by one and find that there are 3 projects subscribe the topic. The 3 projects are:

1.dragonflow
dragonflow/dragonflow/neutron/services/bgp/bgp_plugin.py:94
doesn't use attribute gw_ips, only uses network_id

2.neutron-dynamic-routing
As I said in https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1796629

3.vmware-nsx
vmware-nsx/vmware_nsx/services/dynamic_routing/bgp_plugin.py:83
vmware-nsx subscribe the topic but as Brian said, vmware-nsx overrides the function and doesn't send gw_ips instead of sending router.

vmware-nsx/vmware_nsx/plugins/nsx_v/plugin.py:3545:
overrides the code

Based on the above analysis, there are 3 projects subscribe the topic but only neutron-dynamic-routing process the attribute gw_ips. Thus I think we can fix the bug in neutron.'}, {'account_id': 28961, 'date': '2018-10-10 05:43:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

neutron-vpnaas/neutron_vpnaas/db/vpn/vpn_db.py:717:        if resource == resources.ROUTER_GATEWAY:
neutron-vpnaas/neutron_vpnaas/db/vpn/vpn_db.py:741:        vpn_router_gateway_callback, resources.ROUTER_GATEWAY,

I review the code one by one and find that there are 3 projects subscribe the topic. The 3 projects are:

1.dragonflow
dragonflow/dragonflow/neutron/services/bgp/bgp_plugin.py:94
doesn't use attribute gw_ips, only uses network_id

2.neutron-dynamic-routing
As I said in https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1796629

3.vmware-nsx
vmware-nsx/vmware_nsx/services/dynamic_routing/bgp_plugin.py:83
vmware-nsx subscribe the topic but as Brian said, vmware-nsx overrides the function and doesn't send gw_ips instead of sending router.

vmware-nsx/vmware_nsx/plugins/nsx_v/plugin.py:3545:
overrides the code

Based on the above analysis, there are 3 projects subscribe the topic but only neutron-dynamic-routing process the attribute gw_ips. Thus I think we can fix the bug in neutron.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2018-10-10 05:57:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You don't really need to download all the projects, here is the search url from github:

commit_message:
Fix incorrectly passing ext_ips as gateway ips

An event will be sent out after creating
router gateway. Within the event, ext_ips
is sent incorrectly while gw_ips is expected.
Project neutron-dynamic-routing subscribes
the topic and will process the event. But
it can't process ext_ips.

This commit gets the gw_ips through the
ext_ips and sends gw_ips out.

Co-Authored-By: Allain Legacy<Allain.legacy@windriver.com>

Change-Id: I9b67b58e87faa9cbb8ed4cd03c74f467ca20d73f
Closes-Bug: #1796629

messages: [{'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-26 15:22:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-26 20:00:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:\n\nI actually meant to backport this to stable/rocky but I'll leave this here if anyone still wants it."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-31 18:04:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-26 15:22:49.000000000', 'message': 'PY3: switch to using unicode text values

In Python 3, python-ldap no longer allows bytes for DN/RDN/field
names. Instead, text values are represented as str, the Unicode
text type.

This patch updates the code to adhere to this behavior.

More details about byte/str usage in python-ldap can be found at:
http://www.python-ldap.org/en/latest/bytes_mode.html#bytes-mode

Change-Id: I9ef10432229aaffe4ac9bd733d608098cdae3b9a
Partial-Bug: #1798184
'}]
commit_message:
PY3: switch to using unicode text values

In Python 3, python-ldap no longer allows bytes for DN/RDN/field
names. Instead, text values are represented as str, the Unicode
text type.

This patch updates the code to adhere to this behavior.

More details about byte/str usage in python-ldap can be found at:
http://www.python-ldap.org/en/latest/bytes_mode.html#bytes-mode

Change-Id: I9ef10432229aaffe4ac9bd733d608098cdae3b9a
Partial-Bug: #1798184

[{'created': '2018-10-09 21:04:53.000000000', 'message': "Don't quote {posargs} in tox.ini

Quotes around {posargs} cause the entire string to be combined into one
arg that gets passed to stestr. This prevents passing multiple args
(e.g. '--concurrency=16 some-regex')

Change-Id: I7bb4ca54e9f266c7f2735b0339ea1d7b3138be57
"}]
commit_message:
Don't quote {posargs} in tox.ini

Quotes around {posargs} cause the entire string to be combined into one
arg that gets passed to stestr. This prevents passing multiple args
(e.g. '--concurrency=16 some-regex')

Change-Id: I7bb4ca54e9f266c7f2735b0339ea1d7b3138be57

Is that expected? I guess it would be if the grenade job has n-cpu running queens code. Although I thought in neutron-grenade we were single node and did a full upgrade of n-cpu. So maybe the check runs before n-cpu is restarted with the rocky code?'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 14:37:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

http://logs.openstack.org/02/614302/2/check/neutron-grenade/c626359/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#_Oct_30_22_48_37_109178 is when n-cpu is restarted with rocky code.

And the upgrade check runs at:

2018-10-30 22:48:19.844 | | Check: Console Auths 

So yeah I guess that makes sense, n-cpu is still queens when the check runs and it thinks we're doing a rolling upgrade. Good thing it's a warning and not a failure in the check then."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-10-31 14:43:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add nova-status upgrade check for consoles

This will check if a deployment is currently using consoles and warns
the operator to set [workarounds]enable_consoleauth = True on their
console proxy host if they are performing a rolling upgrade which is
not yet complete.

Partial-Bug: #1798188

 Conflicts:
	doc/source/cli/nova-status.rst

NOTE(melwitt): The conflict is from the absence of the
**19.0.0 (Stein)** section in Rocky and the absence of the placement
API check to require version 1.30 in Rocky.

Change-Id: Idd6079ce4038d6f19966e98bcc61422b61b3636b
(cherry picked from commit d2535b0261205ed80e1731451496caff19ef3f63)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-29 21:46:40.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Avoid setting MTU during live migration if unset

If there is a live migration of an instance that was launched
before change Iecc265fb25e88fa00a66f1fd38e215cad53e7669, it
would not have an mtu set and therefore it wouldn't have it in
the XML.

When live migrating, the mtu is added which changes the
guest ABI[1], causing the live migration to fail.  The failure
occurs when trying to live migrate an instance that:

- Launched before change Iecc265fb25e88fa00a66f1fd38e215cad53e7669
- It has not been rebooted (i.e. XML has not changed since)
- It's using bridge/tap networking
- Migration attempted after change Iecc265fb25e88fa00a66f1fd38e215cad53e7669

This patch prevents this by avoiding setting MTU if the running
instance does not have one configured in its domain XML.

[1]: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1449346

(cherry picked from commit 643f53f5e9544d6c98833b1ae3dd472602118a1f)

Closes-Bug #1800511
Change-Id: I6e2e6437a7c826dc425d8b353c38670d6eece0b5
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Avoid setting MTU during live migration if unset

If there is a live migration of an instance that was launched
before change Iecc265fb25e88fa00a66f1fd38e215cad53e7669, it
would not have an mtu set and therefore it wouldn't have it in
the XML.

When live migrating, the mtu is added which changes the
guest ABI[1], causing the live migration to fail.  The failure
occurs when trying to live migrate an instance that:

- Launched before change Iecc265fb25e88fa00a66f1fd38e215cad53e7669
- It has not been rebooted (i.e. XML has not changed since)
- It's using bridge/tap networking
- Migration attempted after change Iecc265fb25e88fa00a66f1fd38e215cad53e7669

This patch prevents this by avoiding setting MTU if the running
instance does not have one configured in its domain XML.

[1]: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1449346

(cherry picked from commit 643f53f5e9544d6c98833b1ae3dd472602118a1f)

Closes-Bug #1800511
Change-Id: I6e2e6437a7c826dc425d8b353c38670d6eece0b5

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I3a23e8bce371332b4ddee015d6c6adc315769453

glanceclient should use it instead of MD5 to validate data

Change-Id: I4ee6e5071eca08d3bbedceda2acc170e7ed21a6b

commit_message:
Use "multihash" for data download validation

When the Glance "multihash" is available on an image, the
glanceclient should use it instead of MD5 to validate data
downloads.  For cases in which the multihash specifies an
algorithm not available to the client, an option is added
to the image-download command that will allow fallback to
the legacy MD5 checksum verification.

Change-Id: I4ee6e5071eca08d3bbedceda2acc170e7ed21a6b
Closes-bug: #1788323
(cherry picked from commit 8fd7e8c664e82d805dc4a12534b3d7e3fcaac606)

commit_message:
Add scenario tests to gate and check pipeline

Current functional tests executed via trovestack doesn't cover all
integration tests scenarios.

This change extends gate and check pipelines by
trove-scenario-mysql-single job.

Change-Id: I04c53c47b078f4006397f503a58b85ba868ecaac
Signed-off-by: Marcin Piwowarczyk <m.piwowarczy@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Ds8k: Mock evenlet.sleep calls

Unnecessary sleeps during dsk8k unit test runs due to evenlet.sleep
calls not being mocked. Don't do that.

Change-Id: Iac4edfa3082b7833a7122d4626515bb4edb8bd6f
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add --services flag for deploy

Allow users to pass tags to the underlying ansible command.

Added some bare bones unit tests for deploy to ensure the arg is being
parsed and passed down correctly.

Change-Id: I9d321a7a088d09894ae00f41a2ccb6978690b128

commit_message:
report the number of votes needed

Have check_review_status.py report the number of votes needed so the
reader of the output doesn't have to remember that detail about the
rules.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Fix variables for workaround variables.

Drop invalid workarounds keywords
- pre_docker_composable_upgrade_workarounds
- pre_nova_compute_upgrade_workarounds
- pre_docker_converge_upgrade_workarounds
- post_docker_converge_upgrade_workarounds
and use appropriate one:
- pre_overcloud_upgrade_workarounds
- post_overcloud_upgrade_workarounds
- pre_overcloud_upgrade_converge_workarounds
- post_overcloud_upgrade_converge_workarounds

Change-Id: I97eae282bf1ec47b012b89f74b682e6880a7838c
(cherry picked from commit 8cdda0ed23c8c68a40cd35341652b615776a05d5)

We see errors from the ceph-keyring-placement initContainer.

This reverts commit 566a489bbef8ddea4469f7a494b533d60476f016.  It's

Change-Id: I49fa7330f087e806ee0601f104706b762046535d
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Restrict libvirt Ceph access scope to what is needed only."

We see errors from the ceph-keyring-placement initContainer.

This reverts commit 566a489bbef8ddea4469f7a494b533d60476f016.  It's
causing the airship pipeline to break, removing this for now fixes
that and a proper fix can come later.

Change-Id: I49fa7330f087e806ee0601f104706b762046535d

commit_message:
Bump OpenStack service

* Update ceilometer from 11.0.0 to 11.0.1
* Update cinder from 13.0.0 to 13.0.1
* Update horizon from 14.0.0 to 14.0.1
* Update magnum from 7.0.1 to 7.0.2

commit_message:
Adds new neutron nsx plugin parameters

Add dhcp_profile and metadata_proxy config params in neutron nsx
plugin to reflect latest nsx plugin change, and also introduce
a few new config params. The old dhcp_profile_uuid and
metadata_proxy_uuid params are deprecated.

Change-Id: Ibd6d97948dd5416fe66087646acf81821c962cb6

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-29 21:46:40.000000000', 'message': 'Add tests for bug #1800511

In Rocky, we started including the MTU for networks when vif_type
is bridge or tap and libvirt >= 3.3.0, however this also meant
that we started specifying the MTU when doing live migrations.

It seems that the guest ABI changes when setting the MTU which
means that live migrations will fail.  This broke the live migration
of any instance that was launched prior to upgrading to Rocky, as
it was not loaded with the ABI having host_mtu specified.

This is a passing (negative) test-case which will include a follow
up patch that contains a fix and correcting tests.

(cherry picked from commit 29ee8011b4e1cf5371b1aa9c6c0f930eb49fe795)

Related-Bug: #1800511
Change-Id: Ia2fe50d727b1f83e808cb9dda3a55f853f048a3e
'}]
commit_message:
Add tests for bug #1800511

In Rocky, we started including the MTU for networks when vif_type
is bridge or tap and libvirt >= 3.3.0, however this also meant
that we started specifying the MTU when doing live migrations.

It seems that the guest ABI changes when setting the MTU which
means that live migrations will fail.  This broke the live migration
of any instance that was launched prior to upgrading to Rocky, as
it was not loaded with the ABI having host_mtu specified.

This is a passing (negative) test-case which will include a follow
up patch that contains a fix and correcting tests.

(cherry picked from commit 29ee8011b4e1cf5371b1aa9c6c0f930eb49fe795)

Related-Bug: #1800511
Change-Id: Ia2fe50d727b1f83e808cb9dda3a55f853f048a3e

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Add notes about the path of tacker commands

when we install tacker manually in CentOS, the default path of
console scripts such as tacker-db-manage/tacker-server would be
/usr/bin

Change-Id: If4035a058f06275427a2fe5f5a6e949310c13939

@Andery, I think it would make more sense to split Octavia load balancing from the deprecated neuton-lbaas, since Octavia is not a neutron extension.

This runs okay locally on my machine, but which some strange things in the log which see: http://paste.openstack.org/show/719258/

Also, some unit tests fail and after a lot of trial and error, I would really use feedback on those: http://paste.openstack.org/show/719257/'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2018-04-23 13:58:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 26.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2018-04-23 15:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26: Code-Review-1

Reposting the message from gitter:

I against to have separate jobs fo neutron-lbaasV2 and octavia (at least in Rally CI) due to several issues. First of all, I want to have as little as possible number of jobs. That is why we have rally-task-keystone-glance-swift job which combines checking 3 different services. As for neutron-lbaasV2. there is only one plugin and this number will not be extended. Launching only a single job just for one plugin is redundant.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2018-04-23 21:02:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 26:

> Reposting the message from gitter:
 > 
 > I against to have separate jobs fo neutron-lbaasV2 and octavia (at
 > least in Rally CI) due to several issues. First of all, I want to
 > have as little as possible number of jobs. That is why we have
 > rally-task-keystone-glance-swift job which combines checking 3
 > different services. As for neutron-lbaasV2. there is only one
 > plugin and this number will not be extended. Launching only a
 > single job just for one plugin is redundant.

Yup. sorry, I have not addressed this in this PS but I'll change it back.

I struggle with the metric number I see here and what we are trying to measure/test.
Do the metrics count API time, or include the idle/wait time for status to change?
What is the point of creating an LB for each subnet? Is this a concurrency test?
Just given the name of the test, I come away with the impression that it takes much longer to build a load balancer than it actually does, so a bit confused about the metric.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2018-05-31 09:26:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

almost done'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2018-05-31 09:30:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2018-05-31 09:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41:

@Michael:

> Do the metrics count API time, or include the idle/wait time for status to change? 

http://logs.openstack.org/28/554228/41/check/rally-task-load-balancing/0623ae4/results/report.html.gz#/Octavia.create_and_list_loadbalancers

total time includes duration of performing all action as like waiting for specific statuses. As for displaying timings for particular actions, these actions should be marked in proper way. As for current patch-set the only "create" api call is displayed separately, but I left a suggestion how to display wait action as well.

> What is the point of creating an LB for each subnet? 

I suppose it is done to make a new scenario look similar to others. Other scenarios, by historical reasons, did it in such way.

> Is this a concurrency test? 

note: The next answer doesn't relate to this particular "test" by for Rally stuff in general.

What is Rally task (you can call it test suite from qa terms)? It is a combination of subtasks( test cases in qa terms) which consists from workloads (call it tests). Let's talk about workloads.
Workload is a combination of different Rally plugins to perform different load. "scenario" plugin is what one iteration will execute, "runner" plugin is how scenario should be executed and "context" plugin is what should be pre-created before the actual load.
Returning to the current patch:
if you use "constant" runner with the next configuration {"times": 10, "concurrency": 5}, rally will execute "run" method of selected scenario 10 times in 5 threads. It can be called as "concurrency test". Use {"times": 100, "concurrency": 1} and it will not be concurrency test, but the test which verifies that duration of actions do not change in long term. Or you can use "rps" (requests per second) runner to make stress testing. Also, rps runner supports steps which allows you to increase the load, so this test will not be a stress, but identification for the service limits.

CreateAndListLoadbalancers is a scenario plugin which describes what should be executed in one iteration. And it can be used in various number of types of testing

> Just given the name of the test, I come away with the impression that it takes much longer to build a load balancer than it actually does, so a bit confused about the metric.

if you look closer to the report I posted above, there is separate calculation for "octavia.load_balancer_create" action and "total" in general. Unfortunately, "waiting for lb to become in active prov_state" action is not included in the report yet, but it can be easily fixed. Also, the test name is a bit misleading since there is no list action.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2018-08-07 09:29:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42: Patch Set 41 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2018-08-30 12:32:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43: Patch Set 42 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2018-08-31 16:58:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 44.'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2018-09-17 23:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 44:

commit_message:
Port CreateAndListLoadbalancers for Octavia

Ia7a83ebe37a49e58400620b7ed3dedac209664f8 added Octavia client support.
This patch merely ports the existing load balancer (v2) scenario
to use Octavia as an OpenStack top-level project.

The follow-up patch would be additional CRUD scenarios for load balancer
objects such as load balancer (some actions currently missing), Pools,
Health Monitors etc.

Change-Id: Ia865bbe72bfcfa9d96d7f4b628d8c2e1758d7007
(cherry picked from commit d4f5d1eacffd49fb89fab700e6eb13c9a7cdd24c)
Co-Authored-By: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Create configuration options to use JWT

This commit introduces the necessary configuration options and entry
points so that operators can actually use the JWT functionality.

bp json-web-tokens
